summary: This is a memorandum opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The order denies Maxwell's requests for immediate disclosure of alleged victims' identities and for changes to her conditions of confinement, but orders the government to provide regular status updates on her confinement conditions.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, seeking disclosure of alleged victims' identities and changes to her detention conditions.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge issuing the memorandum opinion and order, ruling on Maxwell's motions.

events.title: Maxwell files letter motion
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell files a letter motion seeking disclosure of alleged victims' identities and changes to her confinement conditions.

events.title: Court issues denial order
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan denies Maxwell's requests for immediate victim disclosure and confinement changes, but orders government status updates.

locations: UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF NEW YORK
keyFacts: The court denied Ghislaine Maxwell's request for immediate disclosure of the identities of the three alleged victims referenced in the indictment, calling the request premature.
The court denied Maxwell's request for an order directing the Bureau of Prisons to release her into general population and provide increased access to discovery materials.
The Bureau of Prisons was providing Maxwell with access to discovery materials 13 hours a day, 7 days a week at the time of the order.
The court ordered the government to provide written status updates every 90 days detailing any material changes to Maxwell's confinement conditions.
The charges against Maxwell relate to conduct that allegedly took place many years ago, which the court acknowledged as a factor in considering pretrial disclosure schedules.
